ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about a broad range of topics in network theory and how they apply to economics.
I read a lot of papers across a variety of topics pertaining to graph structure, networks, and game theory. I got a better sense of the applications of theoretical economics and math concepts.
Presentation skills. Reading math-heavy papers.
Helped with presentation skills. Also learned some of the foundation concepts in Network Theory. Learned about a variety of networks
We covered a number of mathematical topics with the theme of networks. So getting to experience all these different topics was good.
Understanding of network theory and other fields of economics.

I learned about some applications of Network Theory in Economics, including auctions, traffic, graph balance, contagion spread, evolution, matching markets, structural power, the structure of the web, link search, and Bayesian and social learning in networks.
Overview of network theory and associated topics

Overview of graph theory, structural balance, strong and weak ties, game theory, network traffic, network structure of the internet, auctions, matching markets, bargaining, information cascades, epidemic model, and more. You will also hone your presentation skills with the three required presentations in class.
A broad survey of topics in economics mostly focusing on networks and game theory and how they fit together in newer emerging subjects in the field.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is very relaxed and you have the possibility to learn about topics that may be interesting to you. The only drawback is that we had to present three times throughout the semester, and the presentations could be on pretty complex topics.
Listening to 1.5 hour presentations over zoom was very tough. It would have been much better in person.
I thoroughly enjoyed that the course was student-led.

Strengths: Dr. Bergemann is an amazing professor. He's crazy smart and well-accomplished, but also very friendly and approachable. He always seemed very attentive to our presentations and made an effort to interject his own expertise. He also suggested we meet in-person for the last class and brought us brownies for it! Dr. Lindenbaum was also really solid and a super smart individual. He definitely cared significantly less about the class though. It was nice having a course second semester senior year with all my fellow econ/math majors. I really enjoyed the fact that there was a separate econ/math section -- it felt like I was seeing all my peers for the last time. The class also has a super manageable workload (three presentations over the course of the semester) and the grading is thankfully super generous (which is really welcome after a tough major). Lastly, I LOVED the textbook. Very clear and thorough yet not overwhelming. The textbook was the right size and difficulty for the class. I felt like I could understand to some degree all the concepts I had to present on.

Weaknesses: The whole structure and premise of the class. Truthfully, this class sometimes felt like a waste of time. "The present three times over the span of the semester" format led to the following: no engagement for 12 weeks and a ton of work for the 3 weeks one presented. I genuinely had no idea what was happening the weeks I didn't present. Further, all my peers are really smart, but it was tough for us to present on material we were neither particularly passionate about (this isn't our thesis) nor particularly knowledgeable about. We ended up basically regurgitating what the textbook said. Lastly, the discussion posts every class were unmanageable. Most courses have a discussion post once a week which I think is much more maintainable. Because we were supposed to do one after every class, no one did them in general. It's tough to put effort into writing one (and read an outside paper) for every class session.
The course is very relaxed and low pressure. The student presentations were good, and so were the discussion posts. The readings were usually interesting as well!
The course would have been much better as an in-person seminar. The discussion post assignments were mostly fruitless.

Each student presented a topic from the textbook with a partner several times, and everyone was encouraged to write a discussion post on each topic. I learned the most during my own presentations. I did not really enjoy the discussion posts, but I appreciated that our professors recognized our difficulties towards the end of the term and indicated that we did not need to catch-up on ones that we had missed.
Pretty chill and tends to be interesting.

Strengths: Everyone gets to present a few of the topics from the book, which helps facilitate conversation in class. By the end we were are chums. Weaknesses: Textbook does not provide much mathematical depth and feels a little outdated.

Having this sort of broad survey of topics is honestly very wonderful. At first it felt a little elementary but towards the end of the course it was nice to see things fit together and talk about modern research on those topics in the discussion posts. I also enjoyed researching the topics and finding papers by Prof. Bergemann and how he's really impacted the fields we were studying.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found that this course adapted very well to an online format given that it was entirely presentation-based (along with discussion posts afterwards).
I thought the professors did a good job of trying to make sure everyone was engaged, although again, it is tough to do a course like this over the virtual format.
Zoom is tough. Watching zoom presentations twice every week can just be tough in general.
It was great that people prepared games.
The one in person class was wonderful. It was the highlight of my senior year.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes; I found this course to be a nice, relaxed closing course for the Economics & Mathematics major!

It is a required econ and math course. I would recommend it anyways as it is a pretty relaxed environment where you learn a lot of interesting concepts. The class is also quite small so you become quite close to the other students.

I wouldn't necessarily recommend it, but it's not the worst required course in the econ/math major. It's honestly not the most fruitful class and you will probably take away very little but that can be fine senior spring. If there was an alternative or I was able to substitute the class for something (even if it was more challenging), I probably would have. Overall, the "student presentation" format of the class isn't really productive to learning. Truthfully, this class sometimes felt like a waste of time. "The present three times over the span of the semester" format led to the following: no engagement for 12 weeks and a TON of work for the 3 weeks one presented (don't underestimate the amount of time it takes to put together a class-length presentation). I genuinely had no idea what was happening the weeks I didn't present. Further, all my peers are really smart, but it was tough for us to present on material we were neither particularly passionate about (this isn't our thesis) nor particularly knowledgeable about. We ended up basically regurgitating what the textbook said. Lastly, the discussion posts every class were unmaintainable. Most courses have a discussion post once a week which I think is much more maintainable. Because we were supposed to do one after every class, no one did them in general. It's tough to put effort into writing one (and read an outside paper) for every class session. 

At the same tine, the course is low workload -- three class length presentations and discussion posts every class for the whole semester is not bad at all (especially because people really stopped doing the discussion posts). The professors are also very generous with final grades and I think most of the class received A's. I appreciated this because it showed how considerate the professors were about our virtual energy levels at this point in our Yale careers. It's also VERY uncommon for econ and math department professors who tend to ignore the outside world/state of the world when setting expectations. The professors themselves are really dope and are just a great energy to be around senior year. I wish they would have been more involved in presenting material in class as I know they were both incredibly knowledgeable. Dr. Bergemann in particular was super approachable and kind and seemed genuinely engrossed in pour presentations even when no one else was. He also brought us brownies on the last day of class. 

All to say, this class won't change your life but it is not a bad way to round out a really challenging econ and math major. I will say: there should be an alternative to this class. This class fell at the same time as two other classes I have desperately wanted to take since my first year at Yale but had never gotten into previously. When I asked the DUS, there was literally nothing I could substitute for it. It's not a productive enough course for that to be true. I could understand if this was a more core theory requirement.
Yes! Well then again, you are probably taking it for your major.

Yes, this course is required for Math & joint majors. Specifically for the Economics and Mathematics majors, I would recommend this course section because it includes background with which we are familiar.
Yes! A nice way to finish of your college vibes.
Yes, if interested in the intersection of mathematics and economics and/or needed to fulfill a senior requirement.
Probably not unless you need to take a math senior seminar, but that isn't to say I didn't enjoy the class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminars, discussion posts
it was a virtual student led presentation. We had one distanced in person class outside at the end of the semester which was so nice.
It was technically a seminar but functioned more like a lecture where different students give the lecture every week.
Weekly student presentations
We had one in-person class at the end of the semester and it was wonderful.
